sec.title: Background/purpose
sec.p: Medical students face a rigorous academic environment that often leads to compromised sleep quality, which is essential for cognitive function, mental well-being and clinical performance. Despite the importance of sleep, a significant percentage of medical students report poor sleep quality, with detrimental effects on their academic performance and overall well-being. Previous research has primarily focused on international populations, leaving a gap in understanding the sleep habits and challenges faced by Canadian medical students.

sec.title: Methods and analysis
sec.p: This cross-sectional study aims to assess the sleep quality among medical students across six Canadian medical schools. The study will use validated instruments, including the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and Epworth Sleepiness Scale, to measure sleep quality and daytime sleepiness. Participants will be recruited via electronic surveys distributed through email and social media. The study will collect demographic data and explore factors impacting sleep quality, such as academic workload, electronic device usage before bedtime and stress levels. Data analysis will involve stepwise multiple regressions to identify predictors of poor sleep quality.

sec.title: Ethics and dissemination
sec.p: Approvals have been granted by the Research Ethics Boards at the University of Ottawa and at each participating site. Results will be reported in a peer-reviewed journal and submitted for presentation at national and international conferences.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: Pan-Canadian scope: By including participants from multiple medical schools across Canada, the study captures a diverse range of sleep experiences among medical students in different provinces, time zones and academic settings.

Validity and expert oversight: Sleep quality and daytime sleepiness are measured using two commonly used tools that have shown valid results—the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and the Epworth Sleepiness Scale—with input and oversight from sleep medicine specialists on the research team to ensure clinical relevance and methodological rigour.

Bilingual and pilot-tested survey design: The survey was professionally translated into French and piloted in both English and French by postgraduate trainees to ensure linguistic accuracy, accessibility and contextual relevance across Canada’s bilingual medical student population.
Reliance on self-reported data: The study’s use of self-reported surveys may introduce recall bias and subjective variations, potentially affecting the accuracy of sleep quality assessments.
Cross-sectional design: As a cross-sectional study, it cannot establish causality, limiting the ability to determine whether certain factors directly impact or correlate with sleep quality.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the demanding environment of medical school, good quality sleep is integral in learners’ health and wellness. Sleep facilitates memory consolidation required during preclinical years and nurtures empathy and clinical judgement developed throughout clerkship.1 2 Paradoxically, the rigorous pace of medical school, which makes sleep essential, may be associated with insufficient sleep, thus posing a risk to learners’ performance and well-being.

Previous research has suggested that sleep disturbance is common in young adults and medical students are no exception. A recent international systematic review and meta-analysis highlighted that 50%–60% of medical students report poor sleep.3 They consistently report restricted sleep quantity with an average duration of merely 6.5 hours per night, and up to one-third of medical students report excessive daytime sleepiness. Students with lower sleep quality report poorer perception of their educational environment, have poorer academic performance4 and perform worse on high stakes clinical assessments such as Objective Structured Clinical Examinations.5

Many factors can contribute to poor sleep among young adults. In medical students, high academic workload, stress induced by fear of failing, on-call responsibilities, the development of harmful behaviours to deal with demanding schedules, and high levels of depression and burnout have been noted.3 Decreased physical activity levels and increased anxiety have been reported elsewhere.4 Increased total screen time is also associated with poor sleep in medical students, although electronic device usage before bed has received minimal attention in this demographic.4 6

The repercussions of poor sleep extend beyond academic performance; poor sleep is associated with lower perception of quality of life among medical students.7 Students who experience substantial daytime sleepiness are more likely to report symptoms of anxiety and depression and lower reported quality of life.7 As medical education increasingly emphasises the importance of resilience, addressing sleep quality and mitigating sleep loss emerge as crucial strategies in combating burnout in future physicians.

Poor sleep and fatigue pose tangible safety risks for medical trainees. Occupational hazards associated with inadequate sleep include elevated risk of needlestick injuries and increased motor vehicle accidents during the commute home.810 While these risks have been demonstrated among medical trainees, studies and potential interventions often focus on resident physicians. There is increased focus on fatigue risk management within residency programmes, with new curriculum standards mandated by the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada.11 Understanding factors influencing sleep quality among medical students prior to residency can inform curriculum changes that may positively impact their medical school trajectory and future careers.

Despite these issues, there is a notable lack of data on the sleep quality of Canadian medical students,3 a gap that persists amid growing awareness of sleep’s importance for cognitive function and mental well-being. Existing studies focus on diverse international contexts, yet the unique academic, cultural and geographical factors including northern latitude and multiple time zones in Canada necessitate investigation.

Canada’s vast geography is unique, spanning six time zones and including northern regions with significant seasonal variation in daylight which can influence circadian rhythms in ways not captured in studies conducted elsewhere. 12Differences in provincial healthcare systems, including clinical exposure, call schedules and resource availability,13 add further variability to the medical student experience. Moreover, students often travel for electives and clerkships that displace them between time zones over short periods of time.14

Canada’s cultural diversity may also uniquely affect sleep. Medical students from diverse religious and cultural backgrounds may observe practices such as Ramadan,15 16 the Sabbath17 or culturally determined evening routines that shift typical sleep-wake cycles. These variations can intersect with demanding academic schedules, potentially compounding sleep disruption. This study addresses these gaps by focusing exclusively on Canadian medical students and examining how these geographical and other factors influence sleep quality. It also explores under-researched elements such as travelling electives, time zone shifts and presleep digital device use.

The proposed study will explore sleep quality among Canadian medical students and has the potential to make significant contributions to the field of medical education, student wellness and policymaking. By addressing the notable gap in current research on the sleep habits of this specific demographic within the Canadian context, our project will highlight the issue and begin to uncover protective factors and stressors. We aim to gain insight into how academic schedules, such as preclerkship and clerkship, impact students’ sleep quality. We will also assess the impact of digital device usage before bedtime on sleep quality, an area that has been poorly studied in this demographic.4 The pan-Canadian scope of the research may offer early insights into the relevance of geographical location, providing valuable context for future studies.

sec.title: Research objective
sec.p: This study aims to assess the sleep quality among Canadian medical students and identify contributing factors to poor sleep. The research seeks to provide foundational data on Canadian medical students’ sleep habits and stressors, informing future interventions to enhance their well-being and academic success.

sec.title: Overall design
sec.p: This will be a cross-sectional study taking place at six medical schools across Canada.

sec.title: Survey development outline
sec.p: Survey design and implementation will be completed according to Phillips.12 The needs assessment, or rationale for the study (step 1), has been outlined in the background. A survey provides the opportunity to seek data from students at multiple medical schools across Canada in a feasible manner. Construction of the draft survey (step 2) is informed by a comprehensive literature review, the clinical expertise of a coauthor (LC, a sleep neurologist) and the lived experience of a current medical student (ZT). For step 3, as a step to establishing validity evidence, the draft survey will be reviewed by the other collaborators, which include leaders in undergraduate and postgraduate medical education and another sleep physician (JYL). To safeguard anonymity, all survey responses will be deidentified, and participants will receive detailed instructions on informed consent through the survey platform. Clear information will outline data handling, storage and usage protocols.

To measure sleep quality, two scales will be used. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) are supported by literature and explore sleep from two aspects—sleep quality and daytime sleepiness (details below), with the latter having previous validity data in the medical student population.18 We aim to strengthen this foundation by examining their applicability within the Canadian student population. The survey will be translated to French by a professional translation service and will be piloted by 4 postgraduate year (PGY)−1 internal medicine residents in English (n=2) and French (n=2) ensuring linguistic accuracy and consistency. Step 4 (survey delivery) details have been provided under participants and recruitment. Step 5—data analysis is provided below. For step 6 the results of the survey will be reported as suggested in the reporting guidelines checklists.19

sec.title: Participants/recruitment
sec.p: Participants will include first to final year medical students (preclinical and clerkship) across six medical schools in Canada. These schools were selected to cover several provinces (Ontario, Alberta and Quebec), different time zones, and 3- year (Calgary, McMaster) and 4-year programmes (Universities of Ottawa, Toronto, McGill, Alberta). Time zones will include Eastern Daylight Saving Time (DST) (Ontario and Quebec) and Mountain DST (Alberta). Student recruitment will be facilitated by the collaborators at each site, who will liaise with their respective undergraduate offices and follow local policies for surveying students. Data collection (ie, survey distribution) will take place between September and October 2024. All students who complete the survey fully (providing implied consent) within the specified period will be included in the study.

Students will be invited to participate via an electronic survey by emails sent out to all students’ institutional emails at each participating school. In addition, students will be invited to participate through school-specific social media groups and pages to ensure broad accessibility and representativeness of diverse student demographics, including those with limited social media engagement. We will also provide an incentive in the form of a gift certificate raffle for participants (6×US$50). This topic is salient to students, which may increase response rates.20 21 Realistically, we will aim for a response rate of 20% or at least 50 participants from each school—we believe sufficient for generating meaningful descriptive insights.21 Participation will be voluntary. The data collection timeline was chosen specifically to avoid the time change at the end of DST, given that this has been demonstrated to have substantial impacts on sleep quality22 and will occur when students are actively engaged in their academic studies. The survey will be offered in French and English. In Quebec and Ottawa, many students would consider French as their first language.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: While patients and members of the public were not directly involved in the overall design, conduct or reporting of this study, efforts were made to involve representative stakeholders in refining the survey tool. Specifically, the survey will be translated into French by a professional translation service to ensure linguistic accessibility for Canada’s bilingual population. Additionally, the survey will be piloted with four PGY-1 internal medicine residents—two in English and two in French—to gather feedback on clarity and relevance. These residents’ insights will guide revisions to the survey, helping to ensure that it is contextually appropriate and accessible for Canadian medical students.

sec.title: Sleep quality and somnolence:
sec.p: Sleep quality is inherently challenging to measure and relies heavily on self-reported metrics using validated clinical scales. Two instruments will be used to measure sleep quality and daytime sleepiness:

The PSQI is a measure of subjective sleep quality and has been extensively used throughout the sleep literature in both clinical and non-clinical populations. In a recent systematic review and meta-analysis, PSQI demonstrated good internal consistency, reliability and validity.23 PSQI is composed of 19 self-rated items regarding insomnia, sleep disturbance and daytime function over the past month, each scored from 0 to 3. A total PSQI score >5 represents poor sleep quality.24 The scale has been translated across 37 languages (including French) and has shown valid results in medical students,25 several patient populations including patients with insomnia and depression, as well as elderly, post-traumatic stress disorder, traumatic brain injury, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pregnancy, fibromyalgia, among many others.

The ESS is a clinical scale used to assess excessive daytime somnolence (EDS).26 This scale has shown valid results when measuring EDS and remains one of the most widely used clinical scales for this purpose.27 An early study specifically assessed validity among medical students and found comparable results when students were retested after a 5-month period.26 The ESS consists of eight self-rated different situations and the subjective likelihood of falling asleep, with each situation rated from 0 to 3. A total score >10 is considered excessive daytime sleepiness.27 A recent abstract at the International Congress on Academic Medicine 2024 listed the ESS as having very good validity data in a medical student population.18

sec.title: Draft survey
sec.p: We will collect participant demographic data (gender, age, university, year of study) and factors that impact quality of sleep such as medication/substance use (including stimulants/hypnotics), diagnosed sleep disorders and medical conditions affecting sleep, other sleep hygiene behaviours (eg, behavioural sleep strategies and apps), social factors such as caregiver roles and information on other cultural/religious factors that might affect sleep. For example, sleep pattern, circadian rhythms, daytime sleepiness and function may change during the month of Ramadan when fasting.15 16 The proposed survey period will overlap Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, which may briefly interrupt daily habits including sleep, although the effects on sleep have not clearly been investigated. The survey will explore potential outcomes of poor sleep such as traffic accidents during commute to/from work or school.8 We will also collect information on electronic device usage before bed.2

In line with Phillips et al’s recommended framework for survey design,20 the development of the questionnaire was informed by a comprehensive literature review, expert input from two sleep medicine specialists and collaborative review by medical education experts. As outlined by Artino et al,19 this contributes to the ‘validity argument’ by grounding the survey content in existing theory and evidence, and by incorporating feedback from qualified experts to enhance content and response process validity. Finally, the survey will be professionally translated into French and pilot-tested with four postgraduate medical residents (two English, two French) to ensure linguistic clarity, contextual appropriateness and usability.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: Stata/SE 15.1 will be used for statistical analysis following the completion of data collection in October. Categorical variables will be expressed as frequencies and percentages, and continuous variables presented as means±SD. Two backward multiple regressions will be conducted using the categorical variables as independent variables and scores on the sleep scales as dependent variables. This type of multiple regression is appropriate to use when an analysis is exploratory and will help identify which variable(s) are predictive of sleep quality. As part of these analyses, we will check for regression assumptions including homoscedasticity and multicollinearity and respond appropriately to correct any issues. Overall model fit will be assessed using an adjusted R-squared. P values and effect size measures will be reported for individual variables. If the number of participants allows, we will also split the data in half for each analysis and compare the resulting models. Doing this will help ensure results are generalisable.

sec.title: Ethical and safety considerations:
sec.p: This study was granted ethical approval by the Research Ethics Board (REB) at each respective site, including the University of Ottawa (Office of Research Ethics and Integrity, ref H-05-24-10336), University of Toronto (Health Sciences REB, RIS 46850), University of Alberta (Alberta Research Information Services, Pro00143579), University of Calgary (Conjoint Health REB, REB24-1062), McGill University (Faculty of Medicine Institutional Review Board, eRAP 24-07-092 IRB A09-E70-24B) and McMaster University (via email confirmation by Dr Lewis from the Protocol Review Committee on 15 August 2024). The research involves a pan-Canadian, cross-sectional survey exploring sleep quality among medical students, using validated self-report instruments—the PSQI and the ESS. Given the nature of the questions, which include queries about daytime sleepiness, substance use (eg, stimulants, hypnotics), and the impact of academic and social stressors, it is acknowledged that some participants may experience minor psychological discomfort or reflect on behaviours that cause concern. However, participation is entirely voluntary, and students may discontinue the survey at any time without consequence. No names or identifying information will be collected in association with survey responses; any email addresses submitted for the optional raffle will be stored separately and not linked to survey data.

The survey will be designed by a team of experts in sleep medicine and medical education to ensure relevance and sensitivity. The survey will be piloted by postgraduate trainees in both English and French. To minimise coercion, participation occurs privately and asynchronously, and all communication emphasises that participation is optional and confidential. No physical, legal or significant psychological risks are anticipated.

sec.title: Dissemination
sec.p: Following completion of data analyses in 2025, findings from this study will be disseminated through multiple academic and public-facing channels. It is anticipated that at least one peer-reviewed Open Access publication will result from this research. The project will also be submitted for poster/oral presentation at relevant national and international conferences.

In addition to academic dissemination, we are committed to sharing findings with medical students, wellness leads and medical education policymakers across the participating institutions. Through these combined strategies, we aim to ensure the findings are accessible, relevant and actionable across diverse audiences, from learners to leadership.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study aims to gain a comprehensive understanding of sleep quality among medical students by examining various influencing factors and outcomes. Prior research has highlighted the importance of sleep for cognitive function and mental health, yet studies were predominantly conducted in Asian and European international settings,3 which may not fully capture the unique challenges faced by North American Canadian students, such as the influence of northern latitudes and multiple time zones. The present study uses a cross-sectional design, enrolling participants from six medical schools across Canada, including those who may not have sought help for sleep-related issues. This broad recruitment strategy aims to ensure a more representative sample of the medical student population, capturing a wide range of experiences and sleep quality levels.

In addition to assessing sleep quality and daytime sleepiness using instruments with valid results such as the PSQI and ESS, this study will explore factors such as electronic device usage before bedtime, academic workload, variation in academic schedules, extracurriculars, exercise and stress levels. By identifying modifiable factors that contribute to poor sleep, the research has the potential to inform targeted interventions aimed at improving sleep hygiene and overall well-being among medical students. To translate findings into practical solutions, results will be shared with medical education stakeholders through presentations, publications and potential collaborations aimed at designing sleep interventions tailored for Canadian medical students.

Study limitations include its reliance on self-reported data which may be subject to recall bias. Additionally, the study does not include perspectives from faculty, administrators or healthcare providers, which could provide further context to the findings. The cross-sectional nature of the study also means that causality cannot be established. Future research should consider longitudinal designs to explore changes in sleep quality over time and the long-term effects of interventions.
